instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.TPS51125: What is TPS51125? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1278 model Macbooks.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_PCH_PWROK: What is PM_PCH_PWROK? PM_PCH_PWROK is usually created by U1950, a 74LVC2G08GT chip and is necessary for the machine to wake from an S5 and S4 state and turn on. This signal will be present if ALL_SYS_PWRGD, CPU_VR_PGOOD, PP3V3_S0, and PP3V42_G3H are present. When this signal is not present or intermittent, usually pin 8 on U1950 for PP3V42_G3H is corroded..
definitions.BATLOW_L: What is BATLOW_L? This signal tells the system that the battery is low, when the signal is low. Anytime you see an “_L” after a signal, that means that the signal is present when it is a low voltage, typically 0 volts to 0.5 volts.
definitions.SMC_BATLOW_L: What is SMC_BATLOW_L? SMC_BATLOW_L refers to a power management signal that indicates a low battery condition. The "_L" suffix suggests that this is an active-low signal, meaning that it becomes low when the battery reaches a low voltage threshold..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
This board had quite a bit of liquid damage. Initially it had no light on the charger and no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. I have put flux and heated all the areas with liquid damage.
 <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> was shorted to ground and the caps on that line were burned on the end so I replaced all of them. The short is gone on there and it now shows 12.58v on it.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.58v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.45v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> both show 0v and there is no short to ground on them.

I have replaced many components that looked bad and they were connected to the 3v3 and 5v rails.
Here are a list of some components I replaced:
<TRANSISTOR>Q7820</TRANSISTOR> and the caps/resistors next to it
<CHIP>U2660</CHIP>, <CAPACITOR>C2600</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C2660</CAPACITOR>
<CAPACITOR>C7943</CAPACITOR> and <RESISTOR>R1923</RESISTOR>
<RESISTOR>R3380</RESISTOR>

<CHIP>U7200</CHIP>(<CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP>) looks spotless with no liquid damage.

I haven't UC'd the board yet so I can save a cleaning.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Is the enable present on pin 13 of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: There is no voltage on Pins 1,6, and 16 of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: That's not an answer. Is the enable present, low, or non-existent?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Pin 16 goes straight to PPBUS through <RESISTOR>R5410</RESISTOR> so there should be 12.56V there. <RESISTOR>R5410</RESISTOR> got voltage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
So you have <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 12.58v

But you have 0v on pin 16 of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>. Pin 16 of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> is <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_5VS3</SIGNAL>. Check <RESISTOR>R5410</RESISTOR>, if <RESISTOR>R5410</RESISTOR> is in-tact, check why <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_5VS3</SIGNAL> is not showing up at pin 16 - most likely blown trace, and run a wire to fix.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: and duke beat me to it :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Okay so I had removed <RESISTOR>R5410</RESISTOR> before because that area was sparking up and causing a little flame when I plugged the charger in.
I forgot to replace it so I just put another one on there and the same thing is happening. I can see a little spark at the trace that is to the right of <RESISTOR>R5410</RESISTOR>. The trace is now exposed a little from being burned.

In diode mode I measured <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> with <RESISTOR>R5410</RESISTOR> on the board and it shows 0.10v. I'm not 100% sure but I believe that number was around 0.35v with <RESISTOR>R5410</RESISTOR> not on the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: So there is a short in the board. Good luck trying to dig that out.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Is it possible for me to get rid of the short? Should I just start scraping that trace?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Start digging, but this will probably be trash.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Okay so I scraped away at that trace and there is no longer a spark when I plug the charger in and the light stays green.

<RESISTOR>R5410</RESISTOR> shows 12.58v on both sides and here are the new measurements from
<CHIP>U7200</CHIP>
Pin 1 - 0v
Pin 6 - 0.73v
Pin 16 - 12.58v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: So <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> present now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Weird. Even though pin 1 of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> is 0v  <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is present at 4.97v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is also present.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> is not present.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> only shows around 1.16v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Why is this weird pin 1 enables the <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> rails. Voltages on <RESISTOR>R1800</RESISTOR>/1/2/3?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Oh okay.
<RESISTOR>R1800</RESISTOR> - pin 1: 3.31v pin 2: 3.21v
<RESISTOR>R1801</RESISTOR> - pin 1: 3.31v pin 2: 3.02v
<RESISTOR>R1802</RESISTOR> - pin 1: 3.31v pin 2: 3.30v
<RESISTOR>R1803</RESISTOR> - pin 1: 3.31v pin 2: 3.30v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Check if <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> is pulsing. Check voltages on Y2605.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> is not pulsing at all.
Pins 1, 2 and 4 of Y2605 all show 0v
Pin 3 fluctuates from anywhere around 0.38v to 0.60v.
<CAPACITOR>C2605</CAPACITOR> was showing around 0.11v but now its showing 0v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Connect a battery, does the light turn orange?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Initially I connected the battery and the battery indicator cable and only a dim green light would show up.
I then plugged in only the battery and the light would just stay bright green.

I ripped the battery indicator cable in the process so I will need to get another one.

Here are some more measurements I took.
0v <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL>
0v <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>
3.3v <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWROK</SIGNAL>
3.44v - <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>
1.17v - <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> and there was liquid damage in that area.
3.41v - <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: What does the battery indicator have to do with charging the batter? Also <SIGNAL>BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> at 1.17V is not correct. Crap under SMC probably

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Okay I UC'd the board and with no battery plugged in I took these measurements
Pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R5041</RESISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q5040</TRANSISTOR> (<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>) show 2.47v
Pin 3 of <TRANSISTOR>Q5040</TRANSISTOR> (<SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>) shows 3.28v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: 2.47V is still not a valid signal. Crap under SMC does not go away with UC. Flux and heat or pull and reball.
